title: 105_s170
content: The "Clone Pager Authorization Act of 1996" amends definitions in the Wire and Electronic Communications Act to include communication made through a clone pager. It also prohibits the use of pen registers, trap and trace devices, or clone pagers without authorization. Chapter 206 is amended accordingly. Chapter 206 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include clone pagers in the regulations regarding pen registers and trap and trace devices. In amending Chapter 206 of title 18, United States Code, clone pagers are included in regulations concerning pen registers, trap and trace devices. The changes involve updating section headings and terms to encompass clone pagers alongside trap and trace devices. The amendment includes clone pagers in regulations for pen registers and trap and trace devices. It authorizes the use of clone pagers in criminal investigations upon court approval. The amendment allows the use of clone pagers in criminal investigations with court approval, including obtaining relevant information through installation and use. The amendment permits the use of clone pagers in criminal investigations with court approval, allowing for the interception of communications. The amendment allows for the use of clone pagers in criminal investigations with court approval for intercepting communications. The amendment permits the use of clone pagers in criminal investigations with court authorization to intercept communications. Government agencies can request providers of paging services to provide necessary assistance for using clone pagers discreetly. The amendment allows the use of clone pagers in criminal investigations with court approval to intercept communications. Government agencies can ask paging service providers for help in using clone pagers covertly. The amendment allows the use of clone pagers in criminal investigations with court approval to intercept communications. Clone pagers are numeric display devices that receive communications intended for another paging device. The Senate passed the amendment on November 7, 1997.
